qas.question: What is recognized as the "first" department store in America?
Where was the store moved in 1857?

answers.text: a five-story white marble dry goods palace known as the Marble House.

qas.question: What made Arnold, Constable stand out from other stores during the civil war?

answers.text: was one of the first stores to issue charge bills of credit to its customers each month instead of on a bi-annual basis

qas.question: When was the "Palace of Trade" built?

plausible_answers.text: a five-story white marble dry goods palace known as the Marble House

qas.question: Where was the store moved in 1875?

plausible_answers.text: was one of the first stores to issue charge bills of credit to its customers each month instead of on a bi-annual basis

qas.question: What made Arnold, Constable stand out from other stores during the revolutionary war?
When was the "Palace of Trade" destroyed?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Arnold, Constable<b5_0/><a0_0/> was the first American department store. It was founded in 1825 by <a1_0><b6_0>Aaron Arnold<b6_0/><a1_0/> (1794?-1876), an emigrant from Great Britain, as a small dry goods store on Pine Street in New York City. In 1857 the store moved into <a2_0><b7_0>a five-story white marble dry goods palace known as the Marble House<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> During the Civil War Arnold, Constable <a3_0><b8_0>was one of the first stores to issue charge bills of credit to its customers each month instead of on a bi-annual basis<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Recognized as an emporium for high-quality fashions, the store soon outgrew the Marble House and erected a cast-iron building on Broadway and Nineteenth Street in <a4_0><b9_0>1869<b9_0/><a4_0/>; this “Palace of Trade” expanded over the years until it was necessary to move into a larger space in 1914. In 1925, Arnold, Constable merged with Stewart & Company and expanded into the suburbs, first with a 1937 store in New Rochelle, New York and later in Hempstead and Manhasset on Long Island, and in New Jersey. Financial problems led to bankruptcy in 1975.
